properties.media:imagetext:
WESTERN AIRLINES
IMPORTANT INFORMATION
You are flying aboard an aircraft with a Flight Crew which is thor-
oughly trained and experienced. It is extremely unlikely that certain
safety facilities will be needed, but simply as a precaution we would
like you to be familiar with these features.
SEAT BELTS
Even if the
"SEAT BELT" sign is turned off in flight, it is recom-
mended that you keep your seat belt fastened, whenever you are in
your seat.
TO FASTEN:
PUSH
TO GE THER
TO RELEASE:
LIFT UP ON THE
TOP OF THE
BUCKLE
SEATBACKS AND TRAY TABLES
Federal Aviation Regulations require your seatback and tray table to
be upright and locked during taxi, take off and landing.
NO SMOKING
When the "NO SMOKING" sign is off, you may
smoke cigarettes only in the
smoking section. Whenever the
"NO SMOKING"' sign is on, extinguish all
cigarettes.
HAND LUGGAGE
Federal Aviation
Regulations require any article of baggage carried
aboard to be placed under a passenger seat.
FLOTATION CUSHIONS
I BRACE POSITION
In the event of a water landing, use seat
bottom cushion for flotation.
Grasp cushion at back and pull from seat
frame.
FEDERAL AVIATION REGULATIONS
No person shall drink any alcoholic beverage aboard an air carrier
aircraft unless such beverage has been served to him by the air carrier
operating the aircraft.
No air carrier shall serve any alcoholic beverage to any person
aboard air carrier aircraft if such person appears to be intoxicated.
No air carrier shall permit any person to board an air carrier air-
craft if such person appears to be intoxicated.
Alcoholic beverages cannot be served to minors.
PORTABLE RADIOS
Federal Aviation Regulation Part 91.19
permits only the following
Portable Electronic devices to be operated aboard Air Carrier aircraft:
1. Portable voice recorders.
2.
Hearing aids
3. Heart pacemakers.
4.
Electric shavers or
5. Any other portable electronic devices that Western's Com-
munications Department has determined will not interfere with
the aircraft Navigation or Communications systems.
Operation of Portable FM Radios is expressly prohibited.
PLEASE SEE OTHER SIDE
SF-456 WAL REV. 1/78 PRTD IN USA

BOEING 737 EMERGENCY EXITS
There are six exits provided for your use. The chart below
will show you the one closest to your seat. The exits over
the wings are removable windows. For easy access to the
windows, push the seatback ahead of the window forward
The two exits at each end of the cabin are doors equipped
with fast operating evacuation slides.
WINDOW EXITS
STEP 2
OVERWING
ESCAPE
ROUTE
AND
LIFT
DOOR EXITS
FORWARD
DOOR
(SLI02)
(SLIDE)
1114
INBOARD
LINBOARD
REAR
CABIN
DOOR
(SLI02)
REAR
GALLEY
DOOR
(SLIDE)
EVACUATION
SLIDE
Jump and
sit in slide
NO SMOKING
BREATHE NORMALLY
BOEING 737 AUTOMATIC OXYGEN SYSTEM
The higher altitudes at which this aircraft operates require
the prompt use of the automatic oxygen system in case of
any sudden change in the cabin pressure. Should this occur,
oxygen masks will drop down. Take nearest mask, pull down
firmly to start the flow of oxygen and promptly place over
nose and mouth.
S5.456 WAL REV. 1/78
2002.127.669
